content.text: State Newton's law of gravitation
Planets have been observed orbiting a star in another solar system. Measurements are made of the orbital radius \(r\) and the time period \(T\) of each of these planets
The variation with \(R^3\) of \(T^2\) is shown in Fig. 1.1
Explain why the gravitational potential energy of the rock is negative
Show that the kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{k}}\) of the rock is given by
Use the expression in **(c)**(ii) to derive an expression for the total energy of the rock
A rock of mass \(m\) is also in orbit around the star in **(b)**. The radius of the orbit is \(r\)
Calculate the number \(N\) of molecules in the gas
The mass of one molecule of the gas is \(40 \text{u}\)
Determine the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of the gas molecules
The temperature of the gas is increased by \(84^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Calculate the value of the ratio
_new_ r.m.s. speed of molecules
original r.m.s. speed of molecules
A fixed mass of an ideal gas is at a temperature of \(21^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The pressure of the gas is \(2.3 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~Pa}\) and its volume is \(3.5 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}^{3}\)
Using a simple kinetic model of matter, describe the structure of a solid
The specific latent heat of vaporisation is much greater than the specific latent heat of fusion for the same substance
Explain this, in terms of the spacing of molecules
Determine the temperature at which the substance melts
temperature =   .........  Â°C
The power of the heater is 150W
Use data from Fig. 3.1 to calculate, in \(\mathrm{kJkg}^{- 1}\), the specific latent heat of vaporisation \(L\) of the substance
Suggest what can be deduced from the fact that section \(\mathbf{Q}\) on the graph is less steep than section \(\mathbf{P}\)

A heater supplies energy at a constant rate to \(0.045 \text{kg}\) of a substance. The variation with time of the temperature of the substance is shown in Fig. 3.1. The substance is perfectly insulated from its surroundings
The defining equation of simple harmonic motion is
State the significance of the minus \((-)\) sign in the equation
Show that the resultant force on the trolley at the moment of release is \(0.77 \text{N}\)
The mass of the trolley is \(250\mathrm{g}\)
Calculate the maximum acceleration \(a\) of the trolley
Use your answer in (ii) to determine the period \(T\) of the subsequent oscillation
The experiment is repeated with an initial displacement of the trolley of \(2.4 \text{cm}\)
State and explain the effect, if any, this change has on the period of the oscillation of the trolley
A trolley rests on a bench. Two identical stretched springs are attached to the trolley as shown in Fig. 4.1. The other end of each spring is attached to a fixed support

The unstretched length of each spring is \(12.0 \text{cm}\). The spring constant of each spring is \(8.0 \text{N} \text{m}^{-1}\). When the trolley is in equilibrium the length of each spring is \(18.0 \text{cm}\)
The trolley is displaced \(4.8 \text{cm}\) to one side and then released. Assume that resistive forces on the trolley are negligible
State what is meant by the amplitude modulation (AM) of a radio wave
State two advantages of AM transmissions when compared with frequency modulation (FM) transmissions
the wavelength of the carrier wave
wavelength =   .........  m
the maximum frequency of the transmitted audio signal
frequency =   .........  kHz
The variation with frequency \(f\) of the amplitude \(A\) of a transmitted radio wave after amplitude modulation by an audio signal is shown in Fig. 5.1
For this transmission, determine:

Another audio signal with the same maximum frequency is transmitted using a different carrier wave frequency. The lowest frequency of this modulated wave is equal to the highest frequency of the modulated wave in (b)
Determine the frequency of this carrier wave
frequency =   .........  kHz
State a similarity between the gravitational field lines around a point mass and the electric field lines around a point charge
state the radius of the sphere
calculate the charge on the sphere
charge =   .........  C
The variation with radius \(r\) of the electric field strength \(E\) due to an isolated charged sphere in a vacuum is shown in Fig. 6.1
Use data from Fig. 6.1 to:
Using the formula for the electric potential due to an isolated point charge, determine the capacitance of the sphere in (b)
capacitance =   .........  F
State the name of this type of amplifier
Show that the gain of the amplifier is 6.0
At time \(t = 0\) the input potential \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) is zero. \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) then gradually increases with time \(t\) as shown in Fig. 7.2
On Fig. 7.2 sketch a line to show the variation with time \(t\) of the output potential \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) from time \(t = 0\) to time \(t = T\).
State how the circuit of Fig. 7.1 may be changed so that the gain of the amplifier is dependent on light intensity
Fig. 7.1 shows the circuit diagram containing an operational amplifier (op-amp)
State the name of the component used as the output device of the op-amp
Complete Fig. 7.3 using the device named in (i) and a diode so that the heater may be switched on when the output of the op-amp is positive
An op-amp is to be used to switch on a high-voltage heater
Draw arrows on the magnetic field lines in Fig. 8.1 around wire P to show the direction of the field
Determine the direction of the force on wire Q due to the magnetic field from wire P
The current in wire Q is less than the current in wire P
State and explain whether the magnitude of the force on wire P is less than, equal to, or greater than the magnitude of the force on wire Q
Two long straight wires P and Q are parallel to each other, as shown in Fig. 8.1. There is a current in each wire in the direction shown
The pattern of the magnetic field lines in a plane normal to wire P due to the current in the wire is also shown
Explain why radio waves are used
Explain why the radio waves are applied in pulses
Nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI) is used to obtain diagnostic information about internal structures in the human body
Radio waves are produced and directed towards the body. The radio waves affect the protons within the body
Define _magnetic flux linkage_
A solenoid of diameter 6.0 cm and 540 turns is placed in a uniform magnetic field as shown in Fig. 9.1
The variation with time \(t\) of the magnetic flux density is shown in Fig. 9.2
Calculate the maximum magnitude of the induced electromotive force (e.m.f.) in the solenoid
State the name of the phenomenon illustrated by the gradual reduction in the amplitude of the dashed line
Deduce which copper sheet is represented by the dashed line. Explain your answer using the principles of electromagnetic induction
A thin copper sheet X is supported on a rigid rod so that it hangs between the poles of a magnet as shown in Fig. 9.3
Sheet X is displaced to one side and then released so that it oscillates. A motion sensor is used to record the displacement of X
A second thin copper sheet Y replaces sheet X. Sheet Y has the same overall dimensions as X but is cut into the shape shown in Fig. 9.4
The motion sensor is again used to record the displacement
The graph in Fig. 9.5 shows the variation with time \(t\) of the displacement \(s\) of each copper sheet
Determine the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) p.d. of the power supply
Determine the period \(T\) of the output
State the name of the type of rectification produced by the diode in Fig. 10.1
On Fig. 10.2 sketch the variation with time \(t\) of the p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) across R from time \(t = 0\) to time \(t = 40 \text{ms}\)
On Fig. 10.1, draw the symbol for a component that may be connected to produce smoothing of \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\)
The power supply is connected to resistor R and a diode in the circuit shown in Fig. 10.1
The output potential difference (p.d.) of an alternating power supply is represented by
where \(V\) is the p.d. in volts and \(t\) is the time in seconds
Explain why a continuous spectrum of energies of X-ray photons is produced
Calculate the wavelength of the highest energy X-ray photon produced
wavelength =   .........  m
Electrons are accelerated through a potential difference of \(15\mathrm{kV}.\) The electrons collide with a metal target and a spectrum of X-rays is produced
Determine the linear attenuation (absorption) coefficient \(\mu\) for this beam of X-rays in the tissue
Determine the thickness of tissue that the X-ray beam must pass through so that the intensity of the beam is reduced to \(5.0\%\) of its initial value
thickness =   .........  cm

A beam of X-rays has an initial intensity \(I_{\mathrm{o}}\). The beam is directed into some body tissue. After passing through a thickness \(x\) of tissue the intensity is \(I\). The graph in Fig. 11.1 shows the variation with \(x\) of \(\ln \left(I / I_{\mathrm{o}}\right)\)
Radioactive decay is both spontaneous and random
State what is meant by:
1. spontaneous decay
2. random decay
Determine the decay constant \(\lambda\) of strontium-90
The activity of the sample after a time of 1.0 half lives is found to be greater than the expected 2.6 MBq
Suggest a possible reason for this
Strontium-90 ( \(^{90}_{38}\mathrm{Sr})\) is an unstable nuclide
The activity of a sample of \(1.0 \times 10^{- 9} \text{kg}\) of strontium-90 is \(5.2 \text{MBq}\)
